Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effective Sequential Procedures for Risk and Error Estimation in Steady-state Simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the development, implementation, and evaluation of a comprehensive methodology for steady-state simulation output analysis in a framework called Effective Sequential Procedures for Risk and Error Estimation in Steady-state Simulation (ESPRESS). Specifically, sequential methods for computing point estimators and confidence intervals for the steady-state mean and selected steady-state quantiles of an output process generated by a probabilistic simulation model will be developed. The confidence intervals will meet prespecified accuracy criteria and achieve a user-specified level of reliability in large samples. The steady-state mean describes long-run average performance, e.g., the average number of vehicles produced per month by an automotive assembly plant operating under a fixed capacity. Steady-state quantiles are used to measure the responsiveness of many service facilities and to characterize the risk associated with financial assets,e.g., the 90th percentile of call-waiting time is often used to evaluate the performance of a call center and the 5th percentile of the Value at Risk for a portfolio of financial assets is frequently used to describe the risk of loss on that portfolio. The implementation phase of ESPRESS will lead to computationally efficient statistical-estimation procedures that users can access and apply easily and quickly, which will be tested in the evaluation phase. The ultimate objective of this work is to provide practitioners and researchers with new techniques and public-domain software for the analysis of steady-state simulations that are completely automated, robust, and reliable as well as computationally and statistically efficient.

If successful, the research will lead to fully automated sequential steady-state mean- and quantile-estimation procedures which are lacking in virtually all widely used commercial simulation packages. ESPRESS will be directly applicable to large-scale simulation studies in the governmental and military sectors as well as in a variety of industries, including aerospace, distribution, finance, healthcare, manufacturing, telecommunications, and transportation. Educational outreach will be a key component of this project, because all three investigators share a deep commitment to engineering education at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Results of this project will be used in developing instructional modules for Project MINDSET (www.mindsetproject.org) and for new courses on Monte Carlo methods and their applications that will be developed at both the master's and doctoral levels at the two participating institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research focused on the development, implementation, and evaluation of a comprehensive methodology for steady-state simulation output analysis in a framework called Effective Sequential Procedures for Risk and Error Estimation in Steady-state Simulation (ESPRESS). Specifically, it developed sequential methods for computing point estimators and confidence intervals (CIs) for the steady-state mean and selected steady-state quantiles of an output process generated by a probabilistic simulation model. In large samples these CIs have been shown to meet pre-specified accuracy criteria on CI length while simultaneously achieving a user-specified level of reliability (i.e., CI coverage probability).

The steady-state mean describes long-run average performance—for example, the average number of vehicles produced per month by an automotive assembly plant operating under a fixed capacity. Steady-state quantiles are used to measure the responsiveness of many service facilities and to characterize the risk associated with financial assets. For example, the 95th percentile of call-waiting time is often used to evaluate the performance of a call center. Similarly, the 5th percentile of the Value at Risk for a portfolio of financial assets is frequently used to  provide a reasonable upper bound on magnitude of a loss that might be incurred on that portfolio during a given time interval (e.g., one trading day). The implementation phase of ESPRESS involved the construction of computationally efficient statistical-estimation algorithms that users can access and apply easily and quickly. The latter goals often cause tradeoffs between the theoretical soundness of a sequential procedure, curtailing the explosion of the procedure’s sampling effort, and the procedure’s applicability in a wide variety of experimental settings. The evaluation phase of ESPRESS entailed thoroughly stress-testing the procedures on problems that possess various degrees of statistical complexities related to the presence of prolonged transient phases, high autocorrelation, and departures of the steady-state marginal distribution from normality. The ultimate objective of this work was to provide practitioners and researchers with new techniques and public-domain software for the analysis of steady-state simulations that are completely automated, robust, and reliable as well as computationally and statistically efficient.

The need for ESPRESS is evident from the lack of fully automated sequential steady-state mean- and quantile-estimation procedures in virtually all widely used commercial simulation packages. By its nature, ESPRESS is directly applicable to large-scale simulation studies in the governmental and military sectors as well as in a variety of industries, including aerospace, distribution, finance, healthcare, manufacturing, telecommunications, and transportation. Efforts are currently underway to implement the ESPRESS algorithms in commercial software.

Educational outreach was a key component of this project, because all three investigators share a deep commitment to engineering education at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. A final primary aim of this project was to increase the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering research activities, including summer internships and ongoing local outreach. The investigators have been active in introducing operations research techniques (including a special emphasis on simulation) to K–12 students and teachers through a long-standing series of local and national workshops and camps over a period of many years. Results of this project will be used in developing instructional and for new courses on Monte Carlo methods and their applications that will be developed at both the master's and doctoral levels at the two participating institutions.
